thread.title: Victory Gives Cubs Hope for Home Playoff Game
thread.title_full: Victory Gives Cubs Hope for Home Playoff Game - The New York Times

author: The Associated Press
title: Victory Gives Cubs Hope for Home Playoff Game
text:
Pinch-runner Eduard Nunez scored from third base on a wild pitch and Torii Hunter hit a sacrifice fly in the ninth inning to give Minnesota a 4-2 victory over the Indians on Thursday night in Cleveland, moving the Twins a little closer to an American League wild-card spot.
Facing a crushing loss, the Twins scored a run in the eighth to tie it and then scored two unearned runs in the ninth against Cody Allen (2-5) to pull one game behind idle Houston for the second wild-card berth, with three games left.
Trevor Plouffe reached on a throwing error by second baseman Jose Ramirez with one out in the ninth. Nunez, running for Plouffe, then raced to third on a single to right by Eddie Rosario before Allen bounced a 2-2 pitch to Hunter in the dirt. Hunter followed with a fly to deep right, bringing in Rosario.
Glen Perkins (3-5) pitched a perfect eighth, and Kevin Jepsen worked the ninth for his 15th save of the season.
CUBS 5, REDS 3 Austin Jackson hit a three-run homer, Anthony Rizzo added a run-scoring double, and Chicago kept alive its slim hopes for home-field advantage in the National League wild-card playoff game with a victory in Cincinnati.
Chris Denorfia also drove in a run, and the Cubs overcame two errors to move two games behind idle Pittsburgh in the race to host the playoff game on Wednesday. Both teams have three to play — Chicago in Milwaukee and the Pirates against the Reds in Pittsburgh.
Joey Votto hit a run-scoring single in the seventh inning, extending his streak of consecutive games in which he has reached base at least once to 47, the longest since Kevin Millar’s 52-game stretch in 2007. Votto’s streak is the second longest in the history of the Reds franchise, behind a 48-game stretch by Pete Rose in 1978.
ORIOLES 6, BLUE JAYS 4 Toronto extended the celebration of its first A.L. East title in 22 years by resting its starters in a rain-delayed defeat at Baltimore.
Manny Machado homered twice for the Orioles, who took a 3-0 lead in the first inning against Drew Hutchison (13-5) before the game was stopped for 3 hours 25 minutes.
Although the Blue Jays are still dueling with Kansas City for the best record in the A.L. — a distinction that will provide home-field advantage through the postseason — Toronto Manager John Gibbons has placed a priority on keeping his players fresh.
David Price, the Blue Jays’ ace, was scratched from his scheduled start. The star sluggers Jose Bautista, Josh Donaldson and Edwin Encarnacion also sat out.
DODGERS 3, GIANTS 2 Brett Anderson pitched two-hit ball into the eighth inning, and Los Angeles wrapped up its road schedule with a victory in San Francisco.
Anderson (10-9) retired 14 straight batters after Kevin Frandsen’s one-out single in the third before Jarrett Parker singled to start the eighth.
Just three balls left the infield against Anderson, and no San Francisco runner reached second base until an error in the eighth inning.
Tim Hudson (8-9) allowed three runs and three hits in two and a third innings in the final start of his 17-year major league career.
